title: Display font used in a company logo
content:
This was supplied as a poor quality print which needs to be reproduced properly.

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [Saro Mar.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20140701151511/http:/typophile.com/files/Saro%20Mar.jpg) | 32.75 KB |
author: Argiolus

comments.content: No repeating letters (to confirm this is a font) and the overall style looks like handwriting - not a font.

Hi, and thanks for your response. It does have repeating characters which are identical — it's just that I edited out any repeating glyphs when I uploaded the sample to WhatTheFont. I'm sure it is in fact a font, though it could well be a digitised handwriting font from a collection or app install.
Sometimes it's better to post the original sample (no resize, no editing at all).

I spent a lot of time searching for this. I searched Dafont and AbstractFonts - no luck. None of the usual ID tools came even close, and keyword searches at MyFonts came up with some similar ones, but no matches. Similar, but not quite as random-looking: [Paquita](http://web.archive.org/web/20140701151511/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/t26/paquita-pro/?refby=bowfin); [Mrs Ant](http://web.archive.org/web/20140701151511/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/hipopotam/mrs-ant/?refby=bowfin); and [Bookeyed Martin](http://web.archive.org/web/20140701151511/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/tart-workshop/bookeyed-martin/?refby=bowfin).

My guess is that this may be a custom made font, which anyone with no lettering skill and about $10 could create.

- Mike Yanega
